title: alani123
author: alani123
content: Ever since bitcoin's early days most people didn't show appreciation. While acknowledgment of bitcoin has increased and demand has risen a lot, it's not necessary that those criticizing bitcoin were wrong. What has bitcoin achieved recently? Getting in more exchanges, getting in ETFs and wider access to traditional markets? Sure. Mining becoming an industry? Ok, let's count that too. Does that mean bitcoin is being appreciated for its values of decentralization and immutability? Probably not. While all this is happening bitcoin fees reached historic lows, which is a sign that there's very little demand to actually transact bitcoin. BTC/USD is near ATH levels and yet we're still here, many people want to trade BTC than ever but almost no one wants to transact with it. We spent so much time talking about lightning and layer two solutions while on-chain transactions can now even be send with a cost of close to nothing and decently fast confirmation. People know that if we all started transacting in bitcoin tomorrow fees would go crazy though. The lightning network is far from usable and even for it acceptance is even lower than bitcoin.But people still don't want to use bitcoin for everyday transactions. El Salvador wanted to pivot to bitcoin to save money on predatory remittance fees and boost its ailing economy that was based on two currencies, a national one and the USD. Still people don't bother to adopt the technology and El Salvador still nearly went bankrupt and had to scrap nearly all bitcoin related plans to receive a small IMF loan. Bitcoin remains hard to use, mining continues to be environmentally damaging to a very large extent while it also becomes more centralized and scalability remains an issue. This price boom changes nothing in terms of fundamentals. Bitcoin's price went up mostly due to external factors but that doesn't solve the issues related to adoption. Maybe though in the end, adoption doesn't matter? What are your thoughts?

comments.author: bitbollo
comments.body: If you look during early days, bitcoin has improved in an impressive way. It was not easy at all spend with low fees your coins. Now you have cards (debits or credit) that allow spending. Many different wallet that implement natively Layer2 (that allow low fees). it's full of service that can offer a product directly with your bitcoin (even gift card).You can also "stake" your coins for earning rewards without spending your coins...I would not see "the half glass empty" but I will look further to these innovations and to next that are coming.Probably main net in the future will be used just as a "final settlement" for you transactions and not for a daily usage. This is not an issue or a failure but something already possible... since the space in a block is limited and must be a "privilege" have a space there.

comments.author: mk4
comments.body: Bitcoin is useful, because BTC works really well for what people mostly use it for — a SoV.Yea, peer-to-peer cash and yada yada, but who are we to tell people what people should use Bitcoin for? Payments are great, but we aren't really strictly constrained to Satoshi's intentions — if anything, SoV is half of Satoshi's narrative. It's just that "peer-to-peer cash" is in the whitepaper's subtitle.

comments.author: Haunebu
comments.body: I must disagree here op. It is true that BTC hasn't been adopted by the mainstream yet, but it has helped solve so many issues ever since it was introduced directly through it or indirectly through other cryptocurrencies. One example is using BTC and other cryptocurrencies to pay for stuff online without worrying about government interference. Also, its fees going to extremely low levels is a good thing making it easier to use for day to day transactions.

comments.author: Marvelockg
comments.body: you have made a lot of good points, but this might be a bit one sided considering that bitcoin is not a perfect invention that was projected to meet all the expectation of it creator or of all bitcoin enthusiast.expecting the next ATH and then another ATH might have been a major consideration among most bitcoin enthusiast at present but that doesn't mean that people dont spend bitcoin or that bitcoin is just about the next price i can get to due to external factors. adoption has grown across all the continent and a lot of people have known bitcoin as the easiest option that works effectively for inter country transaction without necessarily involving the bank. global economic uncertainty has affected all sectors of the worlds economy making the attention of people change from just adopting bitcoin as a payment medium but as a source for some profit hence the reason why the expectation of when the next bull will occure is now mostly talked about. the reason for adoption might not be same with what it use to be at the start but that is also not what critics felt will be the future of bitcoin. they hard a lot of things to point at including the assunmption that bitcoin is another ponzi scheme but overtime, bitcoin have proven them wrong.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Does anyone think critics will ever stop criticizing BTC? Whether it's about those who do it professionally, or those who are just jealous that they didn't invest on time and want the whole thing to fail, it doesn't matter at all - it's important not to pay too much attention to such things. I wouldn't say that those critics were completely right, because you have to remember that many of them said that BTC would disappear in a few years, and it's strange that some stick to that same story even today.Of course, BTC as a currency is not something we can say has succeeded yet, but I think many people are under the misconception that BTC was supposed to replace fiat currencies, when in fact it was supposed to be an alternative to the existing financial system - and I think that for the minority that has accepted it in that way, it is doing an excellent job. The fact is that anyone can make a transaction at any time without depending on a bank, an agency, or seeking permission from anyone, and that is actually a great success.Quote from: alani123 on March 23, 2025, 09:33:03 AM~snip~Bitcoin remains hard to use, mining continues to be environmentally damaging to a very large extent while it also becomes more centralized and scalability remains an issue. This price boom changes nothing in terms of fundamentals. Bitcoin's price went up mostly due to external factors but that doesn't solve the issues related to adoption. Maybe though in the end, adoption doesn't matter? What are your thoughts? I would disagree that the difficulty of use is a problem that prevents people from using BTC in everyday life, because anyone can install a BTC wallet on their smartphone in a few steps, buy BTC on CEX/DEX or some third-party method, and then send it to a BTC address - is it that hard to choose the amount, copy the address, and click send? Maybe for some people it's difficult, but realistically it's something that an average intelligent person can master in 5-10 minutes.What surprises me is that you, as a senior member of this forum, think that BTC mining is a process that harms the environment, while it has been proven countless times that this impact is minimal and that more than 50% of the energy used by mining farms comes from renewable sources. 5-6 years ago, BTC consumed about 0.2% of the total consumption of electricity, which was somewhere around 200 TWh, while the losses in the electricity network were around 50 000 TWh globally.As for centralization, once the problem was China, today it might be the USD - but I think we can never achieve perfect hash rate distribution around the world, because miners always go where the conditions are more favorable for them. In addition, in about 5 years (a little more) the amount of BTC that will remain for mining will approach 1%, so this current fever will probably stop. In my opinion, fewer miners in the future could be a much bigger problem than the fact that today 35%+ of them are stationed in one country.

comments.author: Ultegra134
comments.body: Quote from: Haunebu on March 23, 2025, 11:31:01 AMI must disagree here op. It is true that BTC hasn't been adopted by the mainstream yet, but it has helped solve so many issues ever since it was introduced directly through it or indirectly through other cryptocurrencies. One example is using BTC and other cryptocurrencies to pay for stuff online without worrying about government interference. Also, its fees going to extremely low levels is a good thing making it easier to use for day to day transactions. To pay for what kind of stuff online? The fees are lower for a reason, the number of transactions have gone down a lot, mostly because people aren't actually using Bitcoin, but holding it. Check the following photo to see for yourself, this chart shows the number of transactions for the past 5 years, we're not that far from the lowest point in this time period.As much as I'd like to disagree, the OP is making valid points. El Salvador's plan to convert Bitcoin into a daily currency instead of the U.S. dollar was quite a flop. Yes, El Salvador still holds a significant amount of Bitcoin, and their purchase price is lower than the current one; it's still failed to work in conjunction with the country's currency.I don't agree with all points though. Bitcoin mining is a strenuous and consuming procedure, but just like any other operation, I doubt it's as damaging as a factory in China, etc. With that being said, just as any other operation can function with environmentally friendly ways (such as wind farms, solar panels, etc.), so can Bitcoin. Thus, it's an issue that could easily be solved, while I also believe that Bitcoin mining is the least of our worries for the environment as we speak.

comments.author: macson
comments.body: That's because of the regulation that makes people not use bitcoin in their transactions. people are like "forced" by government regulations to only use bitcoin as their investment, while for regular transactions, they must still use fiat on it.Also, people don't use bitcoin in their regular transactions because of fees. payments using fiat are without fees and waiting time, so it's faster and more convenient to use for regular transactions. but that doesn't mean that no one uses bitcoin for transactions, it's just that it's not often, like for international transactions or P2P.And another reason, people love their bitcoins and just hold them in their wallets to take advantage of the rising bitcoin price. it's just now people understand the value of bitcoin and won't sell it knowing that its value will increase in the next few years.

BTC/USD is near ATH levels and yet we're still here, many people want to trade BTC than ever but almost no one wants to transact with it. We are in a transitional period where it is being adopted but not highly transacted. If traditional businesses start to accept and transact Bitcoin, the network will generate both fees and demand that will continue to appreciate it. At the moment it seems infrastructure is being put into place to make this a reality. As time goes on, it becomes a longer term play. As long as it outperforms and its use case remains relevant, it will remain the best solution.Quote from: alani123 on March 23, 2025, 09:33:03 AMWe spent so much time talking about lightning and layer two solutions while on-chain transactions can now even be send with a cost of close to nothing and decently fast confirmation.  People know that if we all started transacting in bitcoin tomorrow fees would go crazy though. The lightning network is far from usable and even for it acceptance is even lower than bitcoin.Lightning has come a long way and it will probably serve a positive purpose the next time activity goes high, or, lightning/layer 2's will play a pivotal role in acceptance by businesses. This adoption process will take time.Quote from: alani123 on March 23, 2025, 09:33:03 AMBut people still don't want to use bitcoin for everyday transactions. El Salvador wanted to pivot to bitcoin to save money on predatory remittance fees and boost its ailing economy that was based on two currencies, a national one and the USD. Still people don't bother to adopt the technology and El Salvador still nearly went bankrupt and had to scrap nearly all bitcoin related plans to receive a small IMF loan. El Salvador did well until they took a loan from the IMF. Anyone could have seem additional strings and terms coming from that loan from a mile away. Their story is a sign of what happens when trying national adoption happens too early in a nation with low resources.Quote from: alani123 on March 23, 2025, 09:33:03 AMBitcoin remains hard to use, mining continues to be environmentally damaging to a very large extent while it also becomes more centralized and scalability remains an issue. This price boom changes nothing in terms of fundamentals. Not entirely true about environmental damage...at least, it's something that has not been as bad as made out to be and is continually improving. There are a lot of solutions now that are much better for the environment, and as it has been the entire time, there are much worse things that are effecting the environment than mining Bitcoin. Centralization might seem like an issue however I don't think it will be an issue given how many nations are now seeking to make it a part of their critical infrastructure due to benefits it has on e.g. grid regulation. Quote from: alani123 on March 23, 2025, 09:33:03 AMBitcoin's price went up mostly due to external factors but that doesn't solve the issues related to adoption.  Maybe though in the end, adoption doesn't matter? What are your thoughts? While the riches from innovator level adoption might have passed, maturity and wider adoption spans over a much longer period, and it is definitely happening right now. I hope my insights were valuable responses for you and readers

Their story is a sign of what happens when trying national adoption happens too early in a nation with low resources.I'm not so sure about that. Poverty is still rampant at El. Salvador and none of Bukele's policies seem to have addressed it. Surely predatory remittance fees are a big issue but it's not the ONLY issue that can make a country poor. If Buleke wanted to make some long term investments against povery he could have invested in public infastracture and creating some long term jobs in the public sector. Instead last year Bukele was making announcements that after new austerity measures they're debt free. Well so much of the austerity now that it'll have to be followed with even more austerity do comply with IMF terms. Trust me, I'm from Greece, it's been around 15 years since we got the first IMF bailout and we still haven't recovered from the effects of austerity. The IMF doesn't care about the long term wellbeing of a country, all they want is to get paid back fast at any cost. But I'd venture to say that Bukele's policies are more alligned to the IMF than a politician who would care about social wellbeing and would have prioritized to eliminate poverty. He's a neoliberal and likes austerity. The IMF is not much different. That's why he was so quick to abandon bitcoin policies for a minor IMF loan.

comments.author: freedomgo
comments.body: Maybe you’re just focusing on the negative side,  but how about looking at the positives?- Bitcoin is a good hedge against inflation.- Bitcoin is decentralized.- Bitcoin has a limited supply, unlike fiat currency, where governments can just print more.-Bitcoin is considered digital gold.Even just those points are already very positive. Sure, it might not compare to regular digital cash in terms of speed or free transactions, but its transparency is what really sets it apart and makes it valuable.
